hints.content: Start by understanding the input format. You are given a list of points on a line, represented as integers. Make sure you can parse this input correctly before proceeding.
Consider what it means to find the shortest distance between points. The distance between two points, say x1 and x2, can be calculated using the formula |x1 - x2|.
Think about how you might iterate through the list of points to calculate distances. You will likely need a nested loop to compare each point with every other point.
When calculating distances, keep track of the minimum distance found so far. You can initialize a variable to a large number (like infinity) to help with this.
Remember to handle edge cases. For example, if there is only one point in the list, what should the output be? Consider how your approach handles this situation.
Consider optimizing your solution. Instead of using a nested loop, think about sorting the points first. Once sorted, the shortest distance will only need to be checked between adjacent points.
After sorting, you can iterate through the list and calculate the distance between each pair of adjacent points. This reduces the number of comparisons you need to make.
Make sure to handle cases where points might be the same. If two points are identical, the distance between them is zero, which could be the shortest distance.
Think about the return format of your result. You should return the shortest distance as a single integer value, so make sure your final answer is formatted correctly.
Finally, ensure your code is efficient. The sorting step will take O(n log n) time, and the subsequent distance checks will take O(n), resulting in an overall efficient solution.

questionNotes: Input is a list of integers representing points on a line.
You need to calculate the shortest distance between any two points.
Return the shortest distance as a single integer.
Consider edge cases like having only one point or duplicate points.
